messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 59 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Cut-and-Paste Object Insertion by Enabling Deep Image Prior for Reshading

Paper Abstract: Abstract We show how to insert an object from one image to another and get realistic results in the hard case, where the shading of the inserted object clashes with the shading of the scene. Rendering objects using an illumination model of the scene doesn’t work, because doing so requires a geometric and material model of the object, which is hard to recover from a single image. In this paper, we introduce a method that corrects shading inconsistencies of the inserted object without requiring a geometric and physical model or an environment map. Our method uses a deep image prior (DIP), trained to produce reshaded renderings of inserted objects via consistent image decomposition inferential losses. The resulting image from DIP aims to have (a) an albedo similar to the cut-and-paste albedo, (b) a similar shading field to that of the target scene, and (c) a shading that is consistent with the cut-and-paste surface normals. The result is a simple procedure that produces convincing shading of the inserted object. We show the efficacy of our method both qualitatively and quantitatively for several objects with complex surface properties and also on a dataset of spherical lampshades for quantitative evaluation. Our method significantly outperforms an Image Harmonization (IH) baseline for all these objects. They also outperform the cut-and-paste and IH baselines in a user study with over 100 users.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 59 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 59"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Shapes and context: In-the-wild image synthesis & manipulation",
        "Shape, illumination, and reflectance from shading",
        "What is the set of images of an object under all possible illumination conditions?",
        "Intrinsic images in the wild",
        "Remote effects of highlights on gloss perception",
        "An l 1 image transform for edge-preserving smoothing and scene-level intrinsic decomposition",
        "Tracking multiple targets with multifocal attention",
        "Rethinking atrous convolution for semantic image segmentation",
        "Dovenet: Deep image harmonization via domain verification",
        "Rendering synthetic objects into real scenes: bridging traditional and image-based graphics with global illumination and high dynamic range photography",
        "Cut, paste and learn: Surprisingly easy synthesis for instance detection",
        "Revisiting deep intrinsic image decompositions",
        "Intrinsic image decomposition using paradigms",
        "Deep parametric indoor lighting estimation",
        "Fast spatially-varying indoor lighting estimation",
        "Training ‘greeble’experts: a framework for studying expert object recognition processes",
        "Simple copy-paste is a strong data augmentation method for instance segmentation",
        "Image harmonization with transformer",
        "Deep sky modeling for single image outdoor lighting estimation",
        "Drag-and-drop pasting",
        "Rendering synthetic objects into legacy photographs",
        "Automatic scene inference for 3d object compositing",
        "Photo clip art",
        "Color vision and the natural image. part i",
        "Color vision and the natural image part ii",
        "The retinex theory of color vision",
        "Lightness and retinex theory",
        "Context-aware synthesis and placement of object instances",
        "Inverse rendering for complex indoor scenes: Shape, spatially-varying lighting and svbrdf from a single image",
        "Cgintrinsics: Better intrinsic image decomposition through physically-based rendering",
        "Learning intrinsic image decomposition from watching the world",
        "Learning to reconstruct shape and spatially-varying reflectance from a single image",
        "Building a dictionary of image fragments",
        "An approximate shading model for object relighting",
        "An approximate shading model with detail decomposition for object relighting",
        "Microsoft coco: Common objects in context",
        "Region-aware adaptive instance normalization for image harmonization",
        "Image inpainting for irregular holes using partial convolutions",
        "Nerf: Representing scenes as neural radiance fields for view synthesis",
        "Making a “completely blind” image quality analyzer",
        "Real-time joint semantic segmentation and depth estimation using asymmetric annotations",
        "Learning physics-guided face relighting under directional light",
        "Poisson image editing",
        "An image synthesizer",
        "Perceiving shape from shading",
        "On the relationship between radiance and irradiance: determining the illumination from images of a convex lambertian object",
        "A u-net based discriminator for generative adversarial networks",
        "3d photography using context-aware layered depth inpainting",
        "Neural illumination: Lighting prediction for indoor environments",
        "Lighthouse: Predicting lighting volumes for spatially-coherent illumination",
        "Single image portrait relighting",
        "Multi-scale image harmonization",
        "Deep image harmonization",
        "Deep image prior",
        "Cnn-generated images are surprisingly easy to spot…for now",
        "Inverserendernet: Learning single image inverse rendering",
        "The unreasonable effectiveness of deep features as a perceptual metric",
        "Scene parsing through ade20k dataset",
        "Deep single-image portrait relighting"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 59 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Cut-and-Paste Object Insertion by Enabling Deep Image Prior for Reshading, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
